articles.headline: Virus Did Not Bring Financial Rout That Many States Feared
articles.snippet: Grim forecasts held up for a few states, but many took in about as much tax revenue as before the pandemic — sometimes a lot more.
articles.abstract: Grim forecasts held up for a few states, but many took in about as much tax revenue as before the pandemic — sometimes a lot more.
articles.lead_paragraph: Throughout the debate over stimulus measures, one question has repeatedly brought gridlock in Washington: Should the states get no-strings federal aid?
articles.byline: By Mary Williams Walsh and Karl Russell

articles.headline: Myanmar’s Military Deploys Digital Arsenal of Repression in Crackdown
articles.snippet: The generals who staged a coup last month use surveillance drones, iPhone cracking devices and hacking software, some of it from Western countries that bar sales of such technology to Myanmar.
articles.abstract: The generals who staged a coup last month use surveillance drones, iPhone cracking devices and hacking software, some of it from Western countries that bar sales of such technology to Myanmar.
articles.lead_paragraph: During a half century of military rule, Myanmar’s totalitarian tools were crude but effective. Men in sarongs shadowed democracy activists, neighbors informed on each other and thugs brandished lead pipes.

articles.headline: After Stimulus, Biden to Tackle Another Politically Tricky Issue: Infrastructure
articles.snippet: Strengthening the country’s highways, bridges and broadband networks has broad popular support, but Washington remains bitterly divided on the details.
articles.abstract: Strengthening the country’s highways, bridges and broadband networks has broad popular support, but Washington remains bitterly divided on the details.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s two immediate predecessors had ambitious goals to rebuild the country’s infrastructure, but both left office having made little progress in fixing the nation’s bridges, roads, pipes and broadband. President Donald J. Trump announced so many meaningless infrastructure weeks that the term became a running joke of his administration.
articles.byline: By Annie Karni and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: Far-Right Groups Are Splintering in Wake of the Capitol Riot
articles.snippet: The breakdown of larger organizations sets the stage for small groups or lone offenders, who are more difficult to track.
articles.abstract: The breakdown of larger organizations sets the stage for small groups or lone offenders, who are more difficult to track.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just eight weeks after the Capitol riot, some of the most prominent groups that participated are fracturing amid a torrent of backbiting and finger-pointing. The fallout will determine the future of some of the most high-profile far-right organizations and raises the specter of splinter groups that could make the movement even more dangerous.

articles.headline: Amazon Workers’ Union Drive Reaches Far Beyond Alabama
articles.snippet: A vote on whether to form a union at the e-commerce giant’s warehouse in Bessemer, Ala., has become a labor showdown, drawing the attention of N.F.L. players, and the White House.
articles.abstract: A vote on whether to form a union at the e-commerce giant’s warehouse in Bessemer, Ala., has become a labor showdown, drawing the attention of N.F.L. players, and the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: Players from the National Football League were among the first to voice their support. Then came Stacey Abrams, the Democratic star who helped turn Georgia blue in the 2020 election.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Karen Weise

articles.headline: Colleges That Require Virus-Screening Tech Struggle to Say Whether It Works
articles.snippet: Many schools that use fever scanners and symptom checkers have not rigorously studied if the technology has slowed the spread of Covid-19 on campuses.
articles.abstract: Many schools that use fever scanners and symptom checkers have not rigorously studied if the technology has slowed the spread of Covid-19 on campuses.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before the University of Idaho welcomed students back to campus last fall, it made a big bet on new virus-screening technology.
articles.byline: By Natasha Singer and Kellen Browning

articles.headline: Volvo Plans to Sell Only Electric Cars by 2030
articles.snippet: The Swedish company would phase out internal combustion engine vehicles faster than other automakers.
articles.abstract: The Swedish company would phase out internal combustion engine vehicles faster than other automakers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Volvo Cars one-upped larger rivals like General Motors and added momentum to the movement toward electric vehicles on Tuesday by saying it would convert its entire lineup to battery power by 2030, no longer selling cars with internal combustion engines.

articles.headline: The Most Important Gun Lawsuit You’ve Never Heard Of
articles.snippet: A case in New Jersey about Smith & Wesson’s advertising could expose secrets that the industry would prefer to keep hidden.
articles.abstract: A case in New Jersey about Smith & Wesson’s advertising could expose secrets that the industry would prefer to keep hidden.
articles.lead_paragraph: She places her gun in a red leather handbag and gets into her car. The gun, in her bag, sits in the front seat of the vehicle as she drives to work. She then brings the gun, still in the bag, to a meeting with colleagues at the office. She then takes the gun, in her bag, to lunch, where she sits at an outdoor cafe. After that, she goes to the gym — and the gun comes with her. Finally, she goes to a shooting range, where she takes the gun out and fires it at a target. “Nice pistol,” says the man next to her.

articles.headline: Vernon Jordan, Civil Rights Leader and D.C. Power Broker, Dies at 85
articles.snippet: Mr. Jordan, who was selected to head the National Urban League while still in his 30s, counseled presidents and business leaders.
articles.abstract: Mr. Jordan, who was selected to head the National Urban League while still in his 30s, counseled presidents and business leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: Vernon E. Jordan Jr., the civil rights leader and Washington power broker whose private counsel was sought in the highest echelons of government and the corporate world, died on Monday at his home in Washington. He was 85.
